required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Brain Machine Interface Control of an Robotic Exoskeleton in Training Upper Extremity Functions in Stroke
clinical_study.official_title: NRI:BMI Control of a Therapeutic Exoskeleton

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS)

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is:
1. To augment the MAHI Exo-II, a physical human exoskeleton, with a non-invasive brain machine interface (BMI) to actively include patient in the control loop and thereby making the therapy 'active'.
2. To determine appropriate robotic (kinematic data acquired through sensors on robotic device ) and electrophysiological ( electroencephalography- EEG based) measures of arm motor impairment and recovery after stroke.
3. To demonstrate that the BMI controlled MAHI Exo-II robotic arm training is feasible and effective in improving arm motor functions in sub-acute and chronic stroke population.

detailed_description.textblock: This study aims to provide an adjunct to accelerate neurorehabilitation for stroke patients. The MAHI EXO-II, a physical human-robot interface, will be combined with a non-invasive brain-machine interface (BMI) to actively include the patient in the training of upper extremity motor functions.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Fugl-Meyer Arm (FMA) Motor Score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week), 2 weeks after end of treatment, 12 weeks after end of treatment
primary_outcome.description: FMA is a stroke-specific, performance based impairment index. It quantitatively measures impairment based on Twitchell and Brunnstrom's concept of sequential stages of motor return in hemiplegic stroke patients. It uses an ordinal scale for scoring of 33 items for the upper limb component of the F-M scale (0:can not perform; 1:can perform partially; 2:can perform fully). Total range is 0-66, 0 being poor and 66 normal.

primary_outcome.measure: Neural Activity (Cortical Dynamics) Measured by Electroencephalography (EEG) Movement-related Cortical Potential (MRCP) Amplitude
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week)
primary_outcome.description: EEG activity in the low-frequency delta band will be assessed. Scalp EEG electrodes will be located over the motor cortex, specifically, central (Cz, C1- C4), fronto- central (FCz, FC1 - FC4) and centro-parietal electrodes (CPz, CP1 - CP4). Further, to account for left hand vs. right hand impairment, the electrode locations will be flipped for individuals with right hand impairment. Increased MRCP amplitude indicates increased activation of the ipsi-lesional hemisphere or inhibition of competing contra-lesional hemisphere, following motor relearning.

primary_outcome.measure: Cortical Dynamics Measured by Electroencephalography (EEG) Movement-related Cortical Potential (MRCP) Latency
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week)
primary_outcome.description: EEG activity in the low-frequency delta band will be assessed. Scalp EEG electrodes will be located over the motor cortex, specifically, central (Cz, C1- C4), fronto- central (FCz, FC1 - FC4) and centro-parietal electrodes (CPz, CP1 - CP4). Further, to account for left hand vs. right hand impairment, the electrode locations will be flipped for individuals with right hand impairment. MRCP latency is the duration of MRCP prior to movement onset, and is defined as time difference starting from 50% of peak amplitude until the time of movement onset. Increased MRCP latency indicates increased activation of the ipsi-lesional hemisphere or inhibition of competing contra-lesional hemisphere, following motor relearning.

primary_outcome.measure: Movement Quality as Assessed by Exoskeleton Kinematics - Average Speed
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week)
primary_outcome.description: A higher value indicates better movement quality.

primary_outcome.measure: Movement Quality as Assessed by Exoskeleton Kinematics - Spectral Arc Length
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week)
primary_outcome.description: Spectral Arc Length is a frequency-domain measure that increases in value as movements become less jerky. A higher value indicates better movement quality (that is, movements are less jerky).

primary_outcome.measure: Movement Quality as Assessed by Exoskeleton Kinematics - Number of Peaks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week)
primary_outcome.description: Number of peaks is a metric related to the shape of the velocity profile. A higher number of peaks implies jerkier movement. A lower number of peaks indicates better movement quality (that is, movements are less jerky).

primary_outcome.measure: Movement Quality as Assessed by Exoskeleton Kinematics - Time to First Peak
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week)
primary_outcome.description: Time to 1st Peak is a metric related to the shape of the velocity profile, and is reported as [(time to first peak) divided by (total movement duration)]. This value is usually less than the ideal value of 0.5, or 50%, of the total movement duration when a movement has more than one peak. The closer the value is to the ideal value of 0.5, the more well-balanced are the movements.

secondary_outcome.measure: Score on Action Research Arm Test (ARAT)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week), 2 weeks after end of treatment, 12 weeks after end of treatment
secondary_outcome.description: The ARAT is used to assess subject's ability to manipulate-lift-release objects horizontally and vertically, which differs in size, weight and shape. The test consists of 19 items divided into 4 sub-tests (grasp, grip, pinch, gross arm movement) and each item is rated on a 4-point scale. The possible total score ranges between 0-57. Higher scores indicate better performance.

secondary_outcome.measure: Score on Jebsen-Taylor Hand Function Test (JTHFT)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week), 2 weeks after end of treatment, 12 weeks after end of treatment
secondary_outcome.description: The JTHFT is a motor performance test and assesses the time needed to perform 7 everyday activities (for example, flipping cards and feeding). Score is reported as items completed per second.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week), 2 weeks after end of treatment, 12 weeks after end of treatment
secondary_outcome.description: A grip dynamometer will be used to measure maximum gross grasp force.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week), 2 weeks after end of treatment, 12 weeks after end of treatment
secondary_outcome.description: A pinch gauge will be used to measure maximum pinch force.

arm_group.description: MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system will be used to actively include the patient in the control loop, thereby making the therapy 'active' and engaging patients with various impairment severity in rehabilitation tasks. Patients will receive longitudinal training with the BMI-robotic interface for 3-4 sessions per week, over a period of 3 months.

intervention.intervention_name: MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system
intervention.description: In this longitudinal study, adult subjects with hemiparesis due to acute or chronic stroke will receive robotic-assisted training through an EEG-based BMI control of robotic exoskeleton to study the changes in upper extremity motor function, cortical plasticity (using the EEG and fMRI). The training will be provided 3x/week for 12 sessions over one-month period.

overall_official.affiliation: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

facility.name: The Institute for Rehabilitation and Research (TIRR) at Memorial Hermann

link.description: Mechatronics and Haptic Interfaces (MAHI) Lab (Dr.O'Malley, Rice Uni)
University of Houston Brain-Machine Interface System Team (Dr.Contreras-Vidal, UH)
The UTHealth Motor Recovery Lab at TIRR Memorial Hermann Hospital (Dr.Francisco, UTHealth)

reference.citation: A. Gupta, V. Patolgu, M.K. O'Malley, and C.M. Burgar (2008). Design, Control and Performance of RiceWrist: A Force Feedback Wrist Exoskeleton for Rehabilitation and Training, International Journal of Robotics Research (IJRR) 27(2): 233-51.

Bradberry TJ, Gentili RJ, Contreras-Vidal JL. Fast attainment of computer cursor control with noninvasively acquired brain signals. J Neural Eng. 2011 Jun;8(3):036010. doi: 10.1088/1741-2560/8/3/036010. Epub 2011 Apr 15.

Yozbatiran N, Berliner J, O'Malley MK, Pehlivan AU, Kadivar Z, Boake C, Francisco GE. Robotic training and clinical assessment of upper extremity movements after spinal cord injury: a single case report. J Rehabil Med. 2012 Feb;44(2):186-8. doi: 10.2340/16501977-0924.

Bhagat NA, French J, Venkatakrishnan A, Yozbatiran N, Francisco GE, O'Malley MK, Contreras-Vidal JL. Detecting movement intent from scalp EEG in a novel upper limb robotic rehabilitation system for stroke. Annu Int Conf IEEE Eng Med Biol Soc. 2014;2014:4127-4130. doi: 10.1109/EMBC.2014.6944532.

Bhagat NA, Venkatakrishnan A, Abibullaev B, Artz EJ, Yozbatiran N, Blank AA, French J, Karmonik C, Grossman RG, O'Malley MK, Francisco GE, Contreras-Vidal JL. Design and Optimization of an EEG-Based Brain Machine Interface (BMI) to an Upper-Limb Exoskeleton for Stroke Survivors. Front Neurosci. 2016 Mar 31;10:122. doi: 10.3389/fnins.2016.00122. eCollection 2016.

results_reference.citation: Bhagat NA, Yozbatiran N, Sullivan JL, Paranjape R, Losey C, Hernandez Z, Keser Z, Grossman R, Francisco GE, O'Malley MK, Contreras-Vidal JL. Neural activity modulations and motor recovery following brain-exoskeleton interface mediated stroke rehabilitation. Neuroimage Clin. 2020;28:102502. doi: 10.1016/j.nicl.2020.102502. Epub 2020 Nov 19.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 18 were enrolled and allocated to the intervention, but only 10 received the intervention.

group.title: BMI Control of MAHI Exo-II
group.description: MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system will be used to actively include the patient in the control loop, thereby making the therapy 'active' and engaging patients with various impairment severity in rehabilitation tasks. Patients will receive longitudinal training with the BMI-robotic interface for 3-4 sessions per week, over a period of 3 months. MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system: In this longitudinal study, adult subjects with hemiparesis due to acute or chronic stroke will receive robotic-assisted training through an EEG-based BMI control of robotic exoskeleton to study the changes in upper extremity motor function, cortical plasticity (using the EEG and fMRI). The training will be provided 3x/week for 12 sessions over one-month period.

baseline.population: Baseline characteristics are reported for those who received the intervention.

group.title: BMI Control of MAHI Exo-II
group.description: MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system will be used to actively include the patient in the control loop, thereby making the therapy 'active' and engaging patients with various impairment severity in rehabilitation tasks. Patients will receive longitudinal training with the BMI-robotic interface for 3-4 sessions per week, over a period of 3 months. MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system: In this longitudinal study, adult subjects with hemiparesis due to acute or chronic stroke will receive robotic-assisted training through an EEG-based BMI control of robotic exoskeleton to study the changes in upper extremity motor function, cortical plasticity (using the EEG and fMRI). The training will be provided 3x/week for 12 sessions over one-month period.

measure.title: Fugl-Meyer Assessment-Upper Extremity (FMA-UE)
measure.description: FMA is a stroke-specific, performance based impairment index. It quantitatively measures impairment based on Twitchell and Brunnstrom's concept of sequential stages of motor return in hemiplegic stroke patients. It uses an ordinal scale for scoring of 33 items for the upper limb component of the F-M scale (0:can not perform; 1:can perform partially; 2:can perform fully). Total range is 0-66, 0 being poor and 66 normal.

measure.title: Action Research Arm Test (ARAT)
measure.description: The ARAT is used to assess subject's ability to manipulate-lift-release objects horizontally and vertically, which differs in size, weight and shape. The test consists of 19 items divided into 4 sub-tests (grasp, grip, pinch, gross arm movement) and each item is rated on a 4-point scale. The possible total score ranges between 0-57. Higher scores indicate better performance.

measure.title: Jebsen-Taylor Hand Function Test (JTHFT)
measure.description: The JTHFT is a motor performance test and assesses the time needed to perform 7 everyday activities (for example, flipping cards and feeding). Score is reported as completed items per second.

measure.title: NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS)
measure.description: The levels of stroke severity as measured by the NIHSS scoring system are: 0 = no stroke. 1-4 = minor stroke. 5-15 = moderate stroke. 15-20 = moderate/severe stroke.

measure.title: Grip Strength
measure.description: A grip dynamometer will be used to measure maximum gross grasp force.

measure.title: Pinch Strength
measure.description: A pinch gauge will be used to measure maximum pinch force.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Fugl-Meyer Arm (FMA) Motor Score
outcome.description: FMA is a stroke-specific, performance based impairment index. It quantitatively measures impairment based on Twitchell and Brunnstrom's concept of sequential stages of motor return in hemiplegic stroke patients. It uses an ordinal scale for scoring of 33 items for the upper limb component of the F-M scale (0:can not perform; 1:can perform partially; 2:can perform fully). Total range is 0-66, 0 being poor and 66 normal.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week), 2 weeks after end of treatment, 12 weeks after end of treatment
outcome.population: 2 weeks after end of treatment, data for this outcome measure were not collected for 3 participants. 12 weeks after end of treatment, data for this outcome measure was not collected for 1 participant.

group.title: BMI Control of MAHI Exo-II
group.description: MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system will be used to actively include the patient in the control loop, thereby making the therapy 'active' and engaging patients with various impairment severity in rehabilitation tasks. Patients will receive longitudinal training with the BMI-robotic interface for 3-4 sessions per week, over a period of 3 months. MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system: In this longitudinal study, adult subjects with hemiparesis due to acute or chronic stroke will receive robotic-assisted training through an EEG-based BMI control of robotic exoskeleton to study the changes in upper extremity motor function, cortical plasticity (using the EEG and fMRI). The training will be provided 3x/week for 12 sessions over one-month period.

measure.description: FMA is a stroke-specific, performance based impairment index. It uses an ordinal scale for scoring of 33 items for the upper limb component of the F-M scale (0:can not perform; 1:can perform partially; 2:can perform fully). Total range is 0-66, 0 being poor and 66 normal.

class.title: Immediately after end of treatment (within a week)

outcome.title: Pinch Strength
outcome.description: A pinch gauge will be used to measure maximum pinch force.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after end of treatment (within a week), 2 weeks after end of treatment, 12 weeks after end of treatment
outcome.population: 2 weeks after end of treatment, data for this outcome measure were not collected for 3 participants. 12 weeks after end of treatment, data for this outcome measure was not collected for 1 participant.

group.title: BMI Control of MAHI Exo-II
group.description: MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system will be used to actively include the patient in the control loop, thereby making the therapy 'active' and engaging patients with various impairment severity in rehabilitation tasks. Patients will receive longitudinal training with the BMI-robotic interface for 3-4 sessions per week, over a period of 3 months. MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system: In this longitudinal study, adult subjects with hemiparesis due to acute or chronic stroke will receive robotic-assisted training through an EEG-based BMI control of robotic exoskeleton to study the changes in upper extremity motor function, cortical plasticity (using the EEG and fMRI). The training will be provided 3x/week for 12 sessions over one-month period.

measure.description: A pinch gauge will be used to measure maximum pinch force.

Patients will receive longitudinal training with the BMI-robotic interface for 3-4 sessions per week, over a period of 3 months. MAHI EXO-II exoskeleton augmented with BMI system: In this longitudinal study, adult subjects with hemiparesis due to acute or chronic stroke will receive robotic-assisted training through an EEG-based BMI control of robotic exoskeleton to study the changes in upper extremity motor function, cortical plasticity (using the EEG and fMRI). certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Absence of control group, low sample size
